articles.headline: Supreme Court Finds Bias Against White Firefighters
articles.snippet: The justices set new standards for hiring and promotion tests that could have a broad impact on employment law.
articles.abstract: The justices set new standards for hiring and promotion tests that could have a broad impact on employment law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that white firefighters in New Haven were subjected to race discrimination when the city threw out a promotional examination on which they had done well and black firefighters poorly.

articles.headline: Justices Rule That States Can Press Bank Cases
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court cleared state attorneys to investigate national banks for lending discrimination and other crimes, but they must seek a court order first.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court cleared state attorneys to investigate national banks for lending discrimination and other crimes, but they must seek a court order first.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court paved the way on Monday for states to enforce fair-lending laws and other consumer protection measures against the nation’s biggest banks, striking down a rule that limited such powers to federal banking regulators.

articles.headline: In a Coup in Honduras, Ghosts of Past U.S. Policies
articles.snippet: The crisis in Honduras, where the U.S. has a history of backing rival political factions, is pitting President Obama against the legacy of American foreign policy.
articles.abstract: The crisis in Honduras, where the U.S. has a history of backing rival political factions, is pitting President Obama against the legacy of American foreign policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday strongly condemned the ouster of Honduras’s president as an illegal coup that set a “terrible precedent” for the region, as the country’s new government defied international calls to return the toppled president to power and clashed with thousands of protesters.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Marc Lacey

articles.headline: Constant Fear and Mob Rule in South Africa Slum
articles.snippet: Crime in South Africa is often portrayed as an onslaught against the wealthy, but it is the poor who are conveniently accessible to criminals.
articles.abstract: Crime in South Africa is often portrayed as an onslaught against the wealthy, but it is the poor who are conveniently accessible to criminals.
articles.lead_paragraph: DIEPSLOOT, South Africa  The two robbery suspects had already been viciously beaten, their swollen faces stained with rivulets of red. One of them could no longer sit up, and only the need to moan seemed to revive him into consciousness. The other, Moses Tjiwa, occasionally stared into the taunting crowd and muttered, “I didn’t do anything.”

articles.headline: Young Japanese Raise Their Voices Over Economy
articles.snippet: Young people in Japan, who are unemployed at nearly double the overall rate, have started taking to the streets in anger, in protests rarely seen in the country.
articles.abstract: Young people in Japan, who are unemployed at nearly double the overall rate, have started taking to the streets in anger, in protests rarely seen in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  A group of young people recently gathered in a darkened park here. Holding placards and megaphones, they chanted slogans condemning the Japanese government and a lack of jobs and opportunity.

articles.headline: Private Banker Moved Funds Undetected
articles.snippet: Hernán E. Arbizu, a private banker to wealthy clients, says he shifted money to make good on unrealistic investment promises.
articles.abstract: Hernán E. Arbizu, a private banker to wealthy clients, says he shifted money to make good on unrealistic investment promises.
articles.lead_paragraph: He grew up in elite circles in Buenos Aires, acquiring the polish and privileged connections that paved the way for him to become a star private banker in New York to wealthy clients at UBS and JPMorgan Chase.
articles.byline: By Lynnley Browning and Diana B. Henriques

articles.headline: New Planes Will Have Air Bags and Seats Less Apt to Rip Loose
articles.snippet: Additional safety equipment that could help more passengers survive certain crashes will be required on all new aircraft starting Oct. 27.
articles.abstract: Additional safety equipment that could help more passengers survive certain crashes will be required on all new aircraft starting Oct. 27.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  At one time, airline safety generally meant one thing: avoiding a crash. But safety regulators are increasingly focusing on surviving one.

articles.headline: Waiting for Madoff, Angry Crowd Is Disappointed
articles.snippet: Swarms gathered to catch a glimpse of the man who defined an era of greed and fraud on Wall Street.
articles.abstract: Swarms gathered to catch a glimpse of the man who defined an era of greed and fraud on Wall Street.

articles.headline: Iraq Marks Withdrawal of U.S. Troops From Cities
articles.snippet: Iraq’s prime minister offered assurances that security could be ensured, but a suicide bombing that killed at least 33 marred the public holiday.
articles.abstract: Iraq’s prime minister offered assurances that security could be ensured, but a suicide bombing that killed at least 33 marred the public holiday.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Iraq celebrated the withdrawal of American troops from its cities with parades, fireworks and a national holiday on Tuesday as the prime minister trumpeted the country’s sovereignty from American occupation to a wary public.

articles.headline: In 2nd Quarter, Stocks Gained, but for How Long?
articles.snippet: Wall Street finished its best quarter in years on Tuesday, but it would take almost three more rallies to return markets to where they were before the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Wall Street finished its best quarter in years on Tuesday, but it would take almost three more rallies to return markets to where they were before the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: The good news is that Wall Street finished its best quarter in years on Tuesday  part of a dizzy spree that lifted the broad market 35 percent since early March.

articles.headline: Banks Balk at Agency Meant to Aid Consumers
articles.snippet: The administration’s proposal for the new agency marks the first shot in a battle over how to regulate home mortgages, credit cards and other forms of lending.
articles.abstract: The administration’s proposal for the new agency marks the first shot in a battle over how to regulate home mortgages, credit cards and other forms of lending.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Banks and mortgage lenders are placing top priority on killing President Obama’s proposal to create a new consumer protection agency that would regulate home loans, credit card fees, payday loans and other forms of consumer finance.
